item.title: Scuba Divers Discover Priceless Treasure Trove
item.dc:creator: jacobk
item.content:encoded: Time is a story keeper , leaving memories and objects as a path for us to revisit. A group of  unsuspecting scuba divers allowed their curiosities to lead them to the largest cache of gold to be discovered on the seafloor of the Mediterranean Harbor of Caesarea, with most being in nearly mint condition. The group of scuba divers unwittingly noticed the brilliance of what appeared to be a toy coin on the seabed and it was only after further exploring that they quickly realized what they had stumbled upon. The divers excavated the coins and immediately turned them over to the Marine Archaeology Unit of the Israeli Antiques Authority, who have since planned to further unearth the area. The amateur divers displayed great respect for the archaeological find, and have since been deemed model citizens with hearts of gold. This is the largest discovery of gold in Israel, with 2,000 coins uncovered of various denominations with the oldest being a quarter dinar minted in Palermo, Sicily. There are many theories as to the origin of these coins, and how they seemed to surface after over 1,000 years. Kobi Sharvit, director of Marine Archaeology Unit of the antiques authority theorizes “There is probably a shipwreck there of an official treasury boat which was on its way to the central government in Egypt with taxes that had been collected”.  The coins likely surfaced due to storms and natural erosion, luckily this record breaking discovery was not swept to sea. Skilled numismatist Robert Cole had the pleasure of examining the coins and proclaims “The coins are in an excellent state of preservation, and despite the fact they were at the bottom of the sea for about a thousand years, they did not require any cleaning or conservation intervention from the metallurgical laboratory.” The coins are said to be priceless in both their numerical and historical value. Bullion Buddies, what would you do if you unwittingly discovered a gleaming treasure trove of GOLD?

item.title: China To Adopt Gold Standard
item.dc:creator: jacobk
item.content:encoded: The gold standard arose from a widespread acceptance of gold as currency thousands of years ago, and in less than a weeks’ time China will receive approval from its Central Bank to back the Yuan in Gold. Ken Hoffman of Bloomberg Intelligence says this would be a “game changer”, and does not believe the change will be the catalyst to severe constraint for the Chinese Central Bank. He explains in further detail that their decision to move toward the gold standard will help attract foreign capital. Historically moving toward the gold standard enabled the United States to become an International Monetary Fund after World War II. The U.S. held most of the world’s gold, and therefore many countries simply pegged the value of their currency to the dollar, thus making the dollar the defacto world currency. Hoffman states that if they receive approval China’s decision to adopt the Gold Standard will cause the rest of the world to view the metal as currency again.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: China will adopt the gold standard. In less than a weeks’ time China will receive approval from its Central Bank to back the Yuan in Gold.

item.title: Platinum under $1,000/oz for first time since February 2009
item.dc:creator: jacobk
item.content:encoded: Platinum fell underneath the $1,000 an ounce check on Friday, leaving costs in triple-figure region surprisingly since February 2009, as financial specialists kept on losing confidence in its principal interest viewpoint. Vulnerability over the precious metals even with a rising dollar — set for its greatest week by week pick up in two months — is likewise weighing on costs, with gold hitting eight-month lows and palladium at its most minimal since late 2012. Spot platinum fell to a low of $998.50/oz, down 0.7% at 10:41am GMT. Yield from South African platinum makers has been rising this year subsequent to disabling strike activity in 2014. Top player Anglo American Platinum reported a 60% ascent in refined equal generation in the second quarter. Chinese jewelry utilization has been soft this year, while evidences of a stoppage in the worldwide auto industry, which utilizes the metal as a part of exhaust systems, is likewise undermining feeling towards platinum, examiners said. "A major problem is that investors have lost faith in the long-term story and the reason is probably the diesel issue," Macquarie associate director Matthew Turner said.” Information proposes general request in number-one customer China has additionally been soft this year. Mitsubishi examiner Jonathan Steward said platinum turnover on the Shanghai Gold Trade was down 21% in the first half. "With jewelry buying suffering as a result of the equity market crash and economic slowdown, there is possibly more speculative activity than normal, helped by a rotation out of equities and into hard assets," he said in an interview with the Reuters Global Gold Forum this week. "Overall, we are somewhat negative on jewelry fabrication demand this year, and cautious on industrial buying." Platinum has not been underneath $1,000 since mid-2009, after the breakdown of Lehman Brothers and begin of the worldwide budgetary emergency started wide based offering of hard resources and frenzy over the standpoint for mechanical metals request. This year it has been undermined by the way that last year's uncommon five-month strike among platinum excavators in SA — the wellspring of seventy five percent of worldwide platinum supply — neglected to lift costs, recommending shoppers were abundantly supplied. Platinum's generally abnormal markdown to gold has come to its most astounding subsequent to late 2012, at almost $145/oz. That has driven investors to venture over from the business. Gross short positions in NYMEX platinum positions sat at 93% of the record high a week ago, UBS said in a note, while platinum-supported trade exchanged trusts (ETFs) have seen surges this week. Platinum ETFs, which issue securities sponsored by physical metal, saw enormous inflows in 2013 and 2014 after the dispatch of a rand-named item in SA. While those stores have not been intensely sold, inflows have tailed off this year. Based in New York City, Bullion Exchanges remains your direct source for premium  platinum coins and bars.

item.title: Gold ricochets back above $1,100/oz from five-year low

item.content:encoded: Gold rebounded and is above $1,100 an ounce as of last Thursday from the past session’s five year low, as a retreat in the dollar incited financial specialists to exploit the value drop to buy back into the market. Numerous investors remained distrustful towards the precious metal, be that as it may, after its most profound one-day misfortune in about two years last Monday, pushing costs through the chart levels and setting it up for further shortcoming. Gold has been undermined for this present year by assumptions that the U.S. Federal Reserve is on track to raise premium rates without precedent for about 10 years, boosting the expense of holding non-yielding bullion and lifting the dollar. AvaTrade’s chief markey analyst, Naeem Aslam states: "Gold is falling out of favour as the Fed is preparing to increase borrowing costs," "This will remain the major hurdle for any upside move for the precious metal and traders will likely be selling into these rallies. "The bounce in gold is nothing but a technical trade, as most major momentum indicators are showing that the recent sell-off is overdone." Gold’s recession last Monday was exacerbated by huge exchanging volumes on the Shanghai Gold Trade after speculators dumped more than $500,000,000 of bullion in seconds amidst early Asian trading hours. Specialized examiners, who think about past value examples to gage the future heading of the trading, say the following focus for gold underneath last Wednesdays low close to $1,087/oz is $1,044, its 2010 low. Possessions in the greatest gold-backed exchange traded fund, SPDR Gold Shares, shrank for a fifth day last Wednesday to their most minimal since 2008. Some interest developed for physical metal, on the other hand a retreat in the dollar, which fell 0.5% against a currency basket, supported some purchasing in China overnight, merchants said. MKS states: “The on-shore premium in Shanghai continued to trade in positive territory, sitting around $1.50 for the majority of the day, supporting an initial test of $1,100.” The gold debacle last week has prodded a purchasing spree of bullion coin in the United States, as government information demonstrated deals during the current month have hit their most elevated in over two years.

item.title: Gold barely changed ahead of Fed declaration
item.dc:creator: jacobk
item.content:encoded: Gold floated close to its weakest level following mid 2010 on Tuesday, reflecting spectacular delay to offer up bullion in the midst of the developing desire of a close term climb in U.S. interest rates. The Federal Reserve starts a two-day meeting later in the day where policy makers are liable to flag that a rate trek later in the year is sure as the U.S. economy fortifies. A further descend in Chinese equities after their most profound defeat subsequent to 2007 on Monday has scarcely influenced trading in gold, normally seen as refuge metal. ANZ Bank commodity strategist Victor Thianpiriya stated in Singapore, “If anything it’s a little bit surprising that we haven’t had the safe-haven bid in gold even though you’ve had these big risk-off moves in the Chinese equity market”. Spot gold was flat at $1,094.40/oz by 2:50am GMT. Bullion tumbled to as low as 41,077 on Friday, it’s least expensive since February 2010, extending its losing rushed to a fifth week. The prior defeat in Chinese stock in July in addition to the Greek debt crisis neglected to start any place of refuge offer for gold, with financial specialists to a great extent concentrated on an approaching U.S. rate climb. That has reinforced the dollar and diminished the request of non-interest bearing resources, for example, bullion. Financial specialist trust in gold stayed flimsy after last week’s slide joined by enormous trading volumes in New York and Shanghai. The metal lost more than 3% last week, the most since Spring. HSBC, which has sliced its gold value conjectures during the current year and next, said the valuable metal was liable to stay underweight in the fleeting and "could move to within striking distance of $1,000/oz before recovering". The enormous driver for most cost misfortunes for gold is an approaching U.S. rate increment and analysts are anticipating more affirmation from the Fed towards that end when the current week’s policy meetings are set to conclude on Wednesday. “We’re still expecting a fourth-quarter lift off in the Fed funds rate and that’s when you’ll see the trough in gold or we could potentially see gold take another leg lower” said Mr.Thianpiriya, pegging the following significant back at $1,045 if $1,080 is broken once more. U.S. gold for August delivery slipped 0.2% to $1,094.10/oz. Likewise weighing on the assessment, China’s net gold imports from primary channel Hong Kong tumbled to a 10-month low in June, reflecting feeble interest from the major devouring nation.

item.title: Gold stabilizes as investors look for signals on U.S. rate trek timing
item.dc:creator: jacobk
item.content:encoded: Gold steadied on Wednesday as the dollar mollified, yet was still trading near an almost five-and-a-half-year low hit a week ago as analysts and investors anticipated the result of a Federal Reserve meeting for signs on the timing of the first U.S. rate ascend in about 10 years. Policymakers are prone to assert that only steady indications of a  solid U.S. economy and labor market would put them on track to bring interest rates up in advancing months, analysts said. For non-interest yielding gold, higher interest rates mean costs could feel obligated. Robin Bhar, Societe Generale analyst says “We bounced from the low but we are little changed and waiting for the Fed’s statement tonight and the second-quarter gross domestic product tomorrow”. “These are two events that should set direction for the next few weeks although the market is expecting no change in the Fed’s language.” The metal reached $1,077 a week ago, it’s weakest since February 2010, after a sell-off on trades in New York and Shanghai, when analysts and investors cut their vulnerability on apprehensions of further value decays. In the wake of breaking the $1,100 bolster level, gold has found it difficult to recoup and keep afloat showing bearish financial specialists kept on hovering in the market. The dollar declined yesterday and was at 0.2% against a basket dominant currencies ahead of the policy statement due this evening. Commerzbank states “If a rate hike in September were to be signaled, this would doubtless drive up the U.S. dollar, which would ultimately weigh on the gold price, for the Fed Fund Features have so far only priced in roughly 40% of a rate hike in September”. European equities progressed, impelled by additions in the U.S. and Asian markets on trusts that Beijing could stem the defeat in its markets without harm to the world’s second greatest economy. Worldwide gold interest shrank to its most minimal since 2009 in the second quarter as China emptied trusts into its now pained equities market, as per a report by GFMS, a division of Thomson Reuters. Possessions of the biggest gold-backed exchange-traded-fund, New York’s SPDR Gold Trust, were unaltered at 21.87 million ounces on Monday, the least since September 2008, after a seven-day slide. Spot platinum increased 0.6% to $622.75/oz and platinum advanced 0.1% to $982.50/oz, both not a long way above multi-year lows while silver remained unaltered.

item.title: Greek stocks bashed at reopen, while Chinese commodities burdens continue
item.dc:creator: jacobk
item.content:encoded: The Greek stock market plummeted when it reopened on Monday subsequent to being closed down for five weeks, while feeble information from China helped push oil costs to their most reduced in six months and Asian stocks close at their 2015 lows. Analysis revealed China’s factory activity shrunk by the most in two years, guaranteeing a three-month sell-off in commodity and developing markets would proceed. Brent oil tumbled to $51 a barrel, it’s most reduced subsequent to the end of January. Industrial metal copper fell to its weakest in six years. Gold was at $1,093 an ounce after its most exceedingly awful month in two years. Europe was also unstable. Stocks in Athens dove 23% when the market reopened in the wake of shutting down in late June. Lower-evaluated government bonds additionally saw some minor selling. That offset strong economic information. Eurozone processing plant action became quicker than beforehand suspected in July. The Netherlands, Spain, and Italy all reported sound development — Italy’s extension was its best in over four years. Chris Williamson, chief economist at survey complier Markit says “Policymakers will be reassured by the robust growth rates seen in these countries and the resilience of the manufacturing sector as a whole”. “Especially as growth is likely to pick up again now that Greece has jumped its latest hurdle in the ongoing debt crisis.” Energetic results from HSBC, Commerzbank, and Heineken likewise helped balance Greece’s inconveniences. Pickups in Frankfurt and Paris made up for a 0.2% plunge by London’s FTSE. Extraordinary fall of China China’s poor information kept Asian markets from demonstrating the same flexibility. MSCI’s broadest record of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan fell more than 1% to take it near to right on time July’s least level of the year. Shanghai shares shed 1.9%, Japan’s Nikkei slid 0.3% and South Korea Kospi dropped 1%. Australian stocks dropped 0.4%. Barclays strategists wrote in an everyday note to customers, “We believe the macroenviroment remains challenging for emerging market assets amid headwinds of low commodity prices, concerns over China and a looming US Federal Reserve tightening cycle”. New flows data affirmed that pattern. Net remote offering from developing Asia has come to about $10 billion in the course of recent months. Just India has seen lesser inflows. Recent streams information affirmed that pattern. Net remote offering from developing Asia has come to about $10bn in the course of recent months. Just India has seen minor inflows. Among the fundamental worldwide currencies, the dollar held relentless in the wake of sliding on Friday on disillusioning US wage development information, at ¥124.14 and $1.0970 to the euro. Late US financial information has undermined the dollar, yet the more extensive pattern has been to the upside, after the US Federal Reserve invited a rate increment in September during last week’s negotiations. The US dollar has increased 7.75% so far this year against the world's primary trading currencies, following a 12% ascent a year ago. As indicated by examination from the BlackRock Investment Institute “the dollar’s recent rally may just be getting started,” Russ Koesterich of BlackRock says “Since the 1970’s when the Bretton Woods fixed-currency regime ended and currencies began floating, a typical dollar rally has lasted roughly six to seven years”.

item.title: Goldman Sachs and HSBC Buy 7.1 Tons of Physical Gold
item.dc:creator: jacobk
item.content:encoded: On August 6, 2015, Goldman Sachs and HSBC took conveyance of an entirety of 7.1 tons of physical gold. The gold bars were not acquired for bank customers. They were bought for the banks themselves, labelled by the exchange as for shipment to the banks “house” accounts at COMEX. Goldman Sachs, alone, took 3.2 tons worth of physical gold bars. Yet, even as the firm forms its stockpile, Goldman advises customers not to do so. As per Goldman’s Jeffrey Currie, the long haul viewpoint for gold is disheartening.  According to Currie, “In longer term, we definitely like playing this market on the short side. We think we are in a structural bear market, not only in gold, but across the commodity complex, as the individual commodity stories are reinforcing to one another, creating a negative feedback loop.” Despite the shenanigans in the paper-gold market, we know the physical business is ablaze. Interest will surpass known supplies by no less than 1,350 tons in 2015. More in 2016. In any case, that won’t prevent somebody from setting up the paper market keeping in mind the end foal to purchase from the physical market efficiently. This is on the grounds that the baffling gold “supplier last resort” will fill COMEX physical conveyance request, for the minute at any rate, regardless of how high it rises, and regardless of how low different supplies may be. As indicated by HSBC strategists, there has been a: “drift towards Fed tightening and the associated USD strength, low global inflationary pressure, weak gold demand from India and China and market positioning and momentum.” This announcement was made a couple of days before we all found out about the 61% expansion in gold imports to India in the period, April to May. It is impossible that one the greatest players in imports with India did not know this. HSBC officials were positively cunning enough to approve the gigantic buy of physical gold for the bank. In both cases, the buys are enlisted as being for the advantage of the bank, therefore both investors and collectors alike should follow the lead of the banks in purchasing gold.

item.title: Gold set for its most sizable climb since January as stocks, and the dollar slide
item.dc:creator: jacobk
item.content:encoded: Gold stabilized on Friday having hit its most elevated point in over six weeks and was setting out toward its greatest week subsequent to mid-January as further economic data from China has left financial markets shaken. World stocks plummeted towards their most noticeably bad week of the year, while the dollar index hit its least in almost eight weeks after a Chinese production lines information added to questions about the Federal Reserve raising interest rates one month from now. Gold had officially bounced back this week from July’s five-and-a-half-year low, supported by minted of the Federal Reserve’s last strategy meeting, which gouged desired for a fast approaching ascent in US rates. Little change has been seen in spot gold since Thursday, while US gold futures for December delivery were $1.90 at $1,531.30. Naeem Aslam, the Chief market analyst at Ava Trade says “The massive move we have experienced during the past couple of days … was primarily on the back of dollar softness and qualms around emerging markets.” “The Chinese economic date release today has also helped the metal, as this presages more headwinds for the Fed.” “However, now we do need a new catalyst to drive the price any higher and next week’s economic date could certainly fulfill this craving.” Gold has gone under overwhelming pressure this year from possibility that the Fed would raise rates without precedent for about 10 years, lifting the open door expense of holding non-yielding bullion while boosting the dollar. Wall Street plunged at the open, tumbling for the fourth straight session, as the information from China unnerved investors already stressed over the pace of worldwide development. The voracity for danger was further scratched in Europe after Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras stepped down from his position on Thursday. Gold may very well stay bolstered in the transient by further short-covering and safe-haven demands.

item.title: Happy 2015 Diwali
item.dc:creator: jacobk
item.content:encoded: Bullion Exchanges is pleased to offer the PAMP Suisse Gold Lakshmi Bar (In Assay) in multiple denominations and available for purchase today, just in time for the Festival of Lights! Diwali is recognized as one of the most significant festivals in Indian culture, not just for the excitement and abundance that Diwali is known for, but also for the customs including the adorning of homes and businesses with oil lamps, decorating the streets with lavish bowls filled with water and flowers, and ritual baths with fragrant oils. Traditionally, most purchase new clothing, jewelry, and elaborate gifts in celebration of the Festival of Lights. Diwali, takes place this year from November 11-15. This lively celebration observed throughout India with dedication and pride, honors the triumph of good over malevolence and learning over a life of obscurity. Numerous intriguing legends, ceremonies and traditions are connected to the festival, however the most widely recognized legend is of the arrival of Rama Ayodhya following fourteen years of banishment and the demise of Narakasura at the hand of Krishna. For a period of five days Diwali customs and traditions that include the lighting of oil lamps, filling the skies with vibrant firecrackers, worshipping cattle which are regarded as a source of wealth and godliness, decorating homes with colorful Rangoli, and Lakshmi Puja are performed with devotion! Lakshmi Puja takes place on the third day of Diwali, it is on this day that prayers are devoted to the Goddess Lakshmi, the goddess of riches and success. Tradition dictates that Lakshmi will frequent the houses of her believers to shower them with blessings. In hopes of being showered with goddesses affections, a Puja or ritual prayer is offered to Goddess Lakshmi during the evening in each home. A common tradition during the festival of Diwali is the exchange of gifts, with gold being the most highly favored indulgence. Gold is not just a metal in India or purely for investing, it holds incredible nostalgic worth to the people of India for cultural reasons. Gifting gold is customary in many Indian celebrations, it is considered favorable to purchase gold during holidays like Diwali. item.title: The Royal Canadian Mint's latest security enhancements
item.dc:creator: jacobk
item.content:encoded:
Dealers, collectors, and investors have always been concerned about the authenticity of their precious metal investments. For this reason, many world-renowned mints have focused their efforts on the implementation of forefront technologies to enhance the security of their bullion products. The Royal Canadian Mint is one of the few mints to have successfully applied several proven techniques which stand against counterfeiting and ease the bullion verification process. On the 16th of May 2016, RCM made one more step towards reinforcing their famed craftsmanship by introducing the latest security measures for their new 2016 1 Oz. 99.99% Gold Bar. The Royal Canadian Mint is a well-known precious metals refiner and manufacturer, worldwide recognized for its thorough approach to implementing the most innovative security measures. This prestigious mint released the new 2016 1 Oz. 99.99% Gold Bar, which has carried the same weight, size and purity content, since debuting in 1999. What makes it truly special is that the new 1 Oz. Gold Bar includes the latest three RCM security enhancements:
  • The uniform striking line pattern – present on both the obverse and reverse side of the bar – being, at the same time, an exquisite touch of contemporary design and an added security feature;
  • The state-of-the-art micro laser-engraved maple leaf –  already used for the iconic Gold and Silver Maple Leaf coins;
  • The micro-engraved “16” inscription inside the maple leafs – ensuring the authentication of the bar through this new inventive way of displaying its mintage year.
The packaging of these outstanding RCM Gold Bars was also redesigned, mimicking the new lined pattern, on the front side, along with the assay certificate on the back side of the tamper-proof card. The Royal Canadian Mint has already used these bullion security enhancements for its most popular precious metals products. The stunning radial line pattern and the micro-engraved maple leaf privy mark were first introduced for the 2014 releases of the Silver Maple Leaf coin. One year later, the mint started to strike the Gold Maple Leaf coin using the same micro-engraved mark and sunburst radial lines, creating an eye-catching light-diffracting pattern and exclusive luster to these already  famous coins. The latest RCM bullion products to receive the new design and security upgrades are the 1 Kilo Gold Bar and the 100 oz. Silver Bar. Each of these bars is stamped with an individual serial number, the mint’s logo and the hallmarked maple leaf, placed on both sides of the weight stamp. These marks have a raised center and a depressed outline similar to the laser engraved privy mark on Silver and Gold Maple Leaf coin. Also, the serial number on the bars is bordered by vertical lines just like the pattern of the maple leaf. Another one-of-a-kind Royal Canadian Mint security initiative is their Bullion DNA Anti-counterfeiting technology launched in 2014. This cutting-edge technology is based on the unique morphological features of each bullion round, aimed to distinguish fake gold coins, as well as silver editions, from authentic Maple Leaf Coins. To achieve the exclusive textured maple leaf mark, which contains the last two digits of the mintage year which are only visible under magnification, the mint laser-engraves the mark on the dies that are used for striking Gold and Silver Maple Leaf Coins. Then, through use of Digital Non-destructive Activation (DNA) technology, the mint converts, encrypts and registers, in its secure database, a special digital code for every die, which is obtained by capturing a microscopic view of each die’s mark. Therefore, when the Bullion DNA is used in store for identifying any fake maple leaf coin, the security mark of the real coin acts as a fingerprint and matches the complex digital code within the RCM die register, thus confirming its authenticity. This leading edge strategy of the Royal Canadian Mint enhances the protection of its exclusive precious metal bars and coins, thereby ensuring the safety of your future investments.

item.title: Perth Mint will make available its new coin releases starting with September 6, 2016
item.dc:creator: jacobk
item.content:encoded: Perth Mint will make available its new coin releases starting with September 6, 2016 Perth Mint, Australia’s most beloved bullion producer, plans to release at the beginning of this autumn several new coins from its most exceptional series: the brand-new Silver Kangaroo Four-Coin Set, the Star Trek Silver Delta Shaped Coin, the Lunar Rooster Gold & Silver Proof Coins, and the White Lion Cub Silver Proof Coin. ** September will be a huge month with spectacular releases for the Perth Mint, as the prestigious company plans to impress its collectors and numismatists with these fabulous coins:   The brand-new Silver Kangaroo 4 Silver Proof Coin set The newest 2016 Australian Kangaroo Silver Proof Coin set that will contain 4 coins struck from .9999 pure silver in proof quality is the first set from Perth Mint containing four different sizes: 1/10  oz., ¼ oz., ½ oz. and a 1 oz. This set will be produced with an issue limit of 3,000 bundles. All 4 coins depict the latest 2016 Australian Kangaroo design on their reverse side: the bounding kangaroo which is surrounded by stylized sunlight rays. The image of the unofficial symbol of Australia is encircled by the inscription “Australian Kangaroo”, the ‘P’ mintmark, “2016” and the weight and purity of the coin. The Perth Mint offers this gorgeous set in a classic presentation case with a customized shipper and a numbered Certificate of Authenticity. The 4-coin set is simultaneously released with the ¼ oz. Silver Kangaroo Proof coin, which is provided in an individual packaging with a limited issue of 10,000 coins.   Star Trek Delta shaped silver coin – celebrating 50 years of Star Trek This one-of-a-kind release from Perth Mint is an exceptional gift option for Star Trek fans. This 1 oz. .999 pure silver coin will have the shape of the Delta Shield from the famous Star Trek science fiction series produced by Gene Roddenberry, which debuted in 1966 and ran until 1969. The Delta Shield shaped coin will feature the 50th Anniversary Delta Shield logo on its reverse side. The coin will be issued as a Tuvalu legal tender coin, offered in a contemporary acrylic display case, and will be accompanied by a numbered Certificate of Authenticity. The Perth Mint will produce no more than 5,000 of these outstanding coins celebrating the Star Trek 50th anniversary – a true must-have for any Star Trek fan or collector!   The 2017 Lunar Rooster Gold & Silver Proof & Bullion coins The internationally renowned Australian Gold and Silver Lunar Series II will be completed with the 2017 proof and bullion issues that celebrate the Year of the Rooster – the 10th animal in the Chinese Zodiac Calendar. The birth dates for the ‘Year of the Rooster’ are 1921, 1933, 1945, 1957, 1969, 1981, 1993, 2005, and 2017. The people born under this sign are considered as hardworking, honest, loyal, and sociable. These famous Lunar Series coins will be struck from .9999 pure gold and .9999 pure silver in proof and bullion quality. The Lunar Rooster Proof Gold Coins will be available in three sizes, 1 oz., ¼ oz. and 1/10 oz., as well as in a three-coin set. These remarkable coins will have a limited issue: no more than 3,000 1oz. coins, 5,000 ¼ coins, 4,000 1/10 oz. coins and 1,500 three-coin sets. The bullion edition will have an unlimited issue of 1/20 oz., 1/10 oz., ¼ oz., ½ oz., 2 oz., 10 oz. and 1 kg gold coins and a maximum of 30,000 1 oz. coins which are expected to be highly collectable. Both proof and bullions coins will depict on their reverse side the new ‘Year of the Rooster’ design: a rooster standing in front of a stylized Chinese scene with bamboo and leaves, encircled by the inscription ‘Year of the Rooster’, the Chinese character for ‘rooster’ and the ‘P’ mintmark. The Lunar Rooster Proof Silver Coins are also available in three sizes, 1 kilo, 1 oz. and ½ oz. and the three-coin set. These fantastic coins will have a limited issue of 500 1 kilo coins, 5,000 1 oz. coins, 8,000 ½ oz. coins, and 1,000 three-coin sets. The bullion versions will have an unlimited issue of 1 kg, 10 oz., 5 oz., 2 oz., and ½ oz. coins and a maximum of 100 10 kg. and 300,000 1 oz. silver coins. Just like the gold edition, the 1 oz. silver bullion “The Year of Rooster” coin is expected to sell out quickly. Both proof and bullion silver coins feature on their reverse side the new ‘Year of the Rooster’ design: the rooster, hen and the three chicks standing amongst flowers and bamboo, surrounded by the ‘P’ mintmark, the engraving ‘Year of the Rooster’ and the Chinese character for ‘rooster’.   4th issue in the adorable Cubs series – This year’s latest Perth Mint release - the Cub series - will be completed with the fourth coin - the September Cubs - which features the playful white lion cubs from South Africa, Timbavati region. This impressive coin will be struck as a Tuvalu legal tender coin, made from ½ oz. of .999 fine silver with a limited mintage of 5,000 coins, depicting the cute white lion design. The white lion’s color of the coat is white, almost blonde color, which is much lighter than the usual tawny African lion. These lion species are in fact the same, but their white coat is the result of a recessive gene that is carried by both parents which can give birth to both tawny and white cubs. The previous coins depicted the tiger, jaguar and snow leopard cubs and the lynx cub will be depicted on the last, fifth coin in the series. On the reverse side of this amazing coin are depicted two colored white lion cubs that are playing in the savannah’s grass, surrounded by the word “CUBS” and the ‘P’ mintmark. Besides the classic Perth Mint presentation case, the mint also provides a special display box which can be completed with all five coins that will protect and present them in a superb way. ** On the obverse side of each of these coins is engraved the effigy of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II, designed by Ian Rank-Broadley, along with the coin’s face value, weight and purity marks. The Star Trek Delta Shaped Silver coin and 2016 White Lion Cubs ½ Silver Proof Coin also contain the “Tuvalu” inscription, while the obverse side of the other coins contains the “Australia” engraving.   About Perth Mint Perth Mint is the most prestigious Australian Mint, which was established in 1899 by the Royal Mint. The British Mint opened its branch after Britons discovered vast gold deposits in Australia. Today, this premium refinery is accredited by COMEX, DMCC, TOCOM and LBMA, being famous for producing splendid bullion items such as: gold bars, coins, and silver coins, including the Lunar and Kangaroo series. The mint is also famous for creating the finest gold plate made of 13 troy ounces of .999999 pure gold in 1957, which was used as a benchmark by the Royal Mint.

item.title: Bond Jitters and Precious Metals Updates
item.dc:creator: jacobk
item.content:encoded:
Coming into September, and especially with the drop in stocks on Friday, there is a lot of fear about what will happen over the next few weeks in the markets. There seems to be a general sense of unease that develops during September and October, likely due to the high confluence of market crashes that have occurred during this time. The stock market crash of 1929 began in October of that year. The crash of 1987 occurred in October as well. And the financial crisis of 2008 intensified rapidly during September and October. Perhaps there is something ingrained in our seasonal cycle as human beings that leads us to grow cautious as the days become shorter and the temperatures get colder (in the northern hemisphere)... and somehow this innate worry translates into a high correlation with stock market panics over the last 100 years. Friday saw a strong down day in US stocks, as it appears the summer lull has ended for the markets. The S&P 500 Index of US companies fell nearly 2.4% for the day, the largest percentage drop since the day of the Brexit vote in June.     Yet the interesting point is that US 20-year bonds -- which throughout most of history would see safe-haven buying on a strong down day in stocks -- fell on Friday as well. This is most unusual, and merits close monitoring over the months to come, as it is a fundamental component of our long-term thesis for ownership of precious metals. That is: if both stocks and bonds were to fall for the first time in unison over the years to come -- gold would emerge as a final safety asset. Indeed, although gold was down on Friday by 0.6%, it performed well on a relative basis when compared to bonds, which were down 1.6%. Relative strength is an indicator we use quite frequently, as it shows certain investors stepping in to buy one asset, even as most other assets are being sold. This is especially important when comparing typical "safety" assets. While one-day of price action is not enough to call this a trend, in prior articles we have discussed why we are on alert for what will eventually be a 35+ year top in long bonds at some point before the close of the decade. Where will the world turn for safety when US bonds, the asset known to fulfill this role for over a generation, loses its status as such? A long-term decline in bonds coinciding with a long-term decline in stocks would be something never witnessed in modern history... but all signs indicate that it is exactly the scenario which is now brewing. Of course, bubbles are notorious for taking longer to pop than most people expect -- and thus there still may be one more final "blow-off" phase in US bond prices that perhaps could see yields go fully negative (as they have in other countries). But "the writing is on the wall" for what is coming, and it is going to be a fascinating time not only to be an investor, but generally to be a citizen of this world. Gold Update Gold saw nothing less than its fourth attempt this week to overcome the long-term resistance that we have been monitoring for the better part of the last three months, the price level for which currently comes in near $1,360. The price spiked up to $1,356 on Monday and Tuesday, and then once again sellers showed up during the remainder of the week to drive the price back down toward $1,330. This consolidation between $1,300 and the downtrend line referenced in the magenta color has been ongoing for 11-weeks now, and it is nearing a resolution.     The reason we are paying so much attention to the pending break of this long-term trendline is that it is going to represent the shifting in psychology from bear to bull market for the final group of investors who are still clinging to the possibility that gold will be making a new low, below the December 2015 bottom at $1,045. The price action that we witness after these converging sets of trend lines resolve should not resemble what has happened over the last several months. A stronger trending move should occur, which will result in a new wave of investors becoming interested in the sector. Although it appears on the chart above that the converging consolidation could last through February 2017, in studying these types of patterns in the past we can say that they generally do not last beyond the 2/3 timeframe mark. The pattern is currently nearing the half-way mark, and we feel a break is imminent at any time now. It would take a drop in gold below the bottom level of the green support zone -- $1,285 -- to make us question the likelihood for the anticipated advance to come this fall. For now, we continue to see buyers step into the gold market each time the price approaches $1,300.   Silver Update After making another attempt to overcome the key psychological $20 figure, silver fell back starting on Wednesday and finished flat for the week, closing just above $19. Of note is the weakness that silver saw on Friday relative to gold, falling 2.8% to gold's 0.6% by the close of the day. This phenomenon is common on days when the stock market is seeing a strong sell-off and gold is falling even modestly. In such instances silver tends to multiply the losses in the two markets, seeing selling both from the precious metals sector and also from the industrial sector. In a steady stock market with rising gold prices, it is often the case that silver will amplify the gains in gold as it benefits from both sectors. This is all part of silver's dual-personality behavior, which makes it one of the most interesting yet volatile commodities in the world. We are now seeing 5% intra-week swings in this precious metal, which will only amplify over the next few years. With the approach of $20 this week and then backing off again into the mid-range of the consolidation, silver's short-term pattern is increasingly appearing to be a bull-flag correction. Seen often on individual stocks, this pattern generally represents a half-way downward-sloping pause in a primary advance.     In this case, the surge (or "pole" of the flag pole) was from early June at $15.80 through July at $21.25: an amplitude of $5.45. Silver made a 2-week bottom in mid-August at $18.50, and it is quite possible that this was the low for the bull flag correction. With an amplitude of $5.45, the pattern would target a silver price of $25.45 when added to the breakout point of the flag. Such is in line with our expectations for silver's seasonal advance to come. We will confirm the pattern when the short-term (dashed teal-color) resistance line is broken to the upside. Our worst-case scenario would be for silver to fall into the lower range of the green support band near $17.50 prior to its next attempt at an advance.
Christopher Aaron, Bullion Exchanges Market Analyst Christopher Aaron has been trading in the commodity and financial markets since the early 2000's. He began his career as an intelligence analyst for the Central Intelligence Agency, where he specialized in the creation and interpretation of pattern-of- life mapping in Afghanistan and Iraq. Technical analysis shares many similarities with mapping: both are based on the observations of repeating and imbedded patterns in human nature. His strategy of blending behavioral and technical analysis has helped him and his clients to identify both long-term market cycles and short-term opportunities for profit. This article is provided as a third party analysis and does not necessarily matches views of Bullion Exchanges and should not be considered as financial advice in any way.

item.title: Rising Interest Rates Correspond with Rising Gold Prices
item.dc:creator: jacobk
item.content:encoded:
Gold's summer consolidation stretches on for another week, and this time tests the lower boundary of the support zone labeled below, closing at $1,310. For the week, the international currency of last resort closed down by $24 or some 1.8%. This was the 4th distinct hit on the green support zone since June, which closely matches the number of attempts gold has made to overcome the long-term downtrend shown below in magenta. All eyes now turn to the US Federal Reserve policy meeting on Wednesday as the next likely catalyst to kick gold out of this consolidation in one way or another. On the subject of the coming Fed meeting, there is a continuous falsehood portrayed in the mainstream media regarding the effects of rising interest rates on the prices of precious metals. Another one of these misleading articles was published this week in Bloomberg.   The falsehood is that rising interest rates are negative for precious metals. The theory is that rising interest rates increase the attractiveness of interest-bearing accounts, such as US dollar-denominated bonds or savings accounts. This, in turn, should cause investors to turn away from gold, as it pays no interest. The mainstream media will publish articles explaining this theory every few months, typically when gold has been weak in price, as a way to explain the recent trading action. Here is a snippet of the recent article from Bloomberg and the highlighted section reveals the erroneous statement: "Gold would get hit pretty hard in a rising rate environment." Yet the actual data for rising interest rates and precious metals prices is completely contrary to this statement. All we need to do is examine the history of rising interest rate cycles and gold prices, and the correlation is plain to see.   Interest Rates and Precious Metals Prices Let us give two examples to illustrate the true correlation between short-term interest rates and precious metals prices. First, the example from the most recent multi-year rate hike cycle. Below is a chart of the 2003 - 2007 time period, showing short-term interest rates rising from 1% to 5.25%. Following that is a chart of gold prices over the same time period.   Here, we can clearly see that a rise in interest rates corresponded to a rise in gold prices, as the price of the metal rose from $325 to over $800 during this same time period. Now let us look at a longer-term example, the multi-decade rise in interest rates from 1955 - 1980. To be as concise as possible: a rising interest rate environment over these 25 years was the backdrop to the largest precious metals bull market in modern history, as gold broke the dollar standard at $35 per ounce and advanced over 2,000% through 1980.   Why do precious metals rise with rising interest rates? In order for this to make sense, we must alter our perspective of the Federal Reserve from what is discussed in the news. The Fed is a reactive, not a proactive organization. The Fed responds to incoming data related to prices, employment, and the solvency of its own member banks -- and then responds with monetary policy after the fact. The Fed has no crystal ball. Being reactive, when would the Fed logically decide to raise interest rates? Only when it is forced to do so. In other words, the Fed raises interest rates only when the inflationary effects of its previous money-printing cycle are starting to be obvious in the broader economy. Gold is the ultimate protection from inflation, and this is why it tends to rise in a rising interest rate environment. Like a well-trained hound, gold sniffs out looming inflation better than any data possibly could. It is uncertain why the mainstream media continues to purport this false idea regarding rising interest rates and precious metals prices. It may simply be one of those myths that takes on a life of its own, or it may be scare tactics designed to separate investors from their gold at critical junctures. Regardless of the cause, one would think that such prominent news organizations would check their data before publishing these claims. So, for the record: when do gold prices fall relative to interest rates? A careful look at the correlation between gold bear markets and interest rate cycles over the last 70 years reveals that gold typically declines after the peak of a rate cycle and as rates remain falling or low. Such was the case for the peak and subsequent declines in gold both in 1980 and in 2011. Current interest rates at 0.25 - 0.50%, having fallen since 2008 in the short-term cycle and since 1980 in the long-term cycle, are nowhere near a peak at this juncture. If anything rates are now forming a long-term low, from which we may see decades of increases into the future.   One Final Point  This long-term perspective does not necessarily mean that gold will rise on the day of a Fed interest rate hike, whether it be this week, or at the next meeting in December. As ironic as it may be, some short-term traders believe the myth they have been taught through these erroneous articles, and so it becomes self-fulfilling as they sell gold on the news of a rate hike.  All the while, long-term investors are accumulating the metal knowing that the inflation from years of money-printing is starting to appear in the system. Do not be mislead by the mainstream press: the Fed is reactionary. It increases rates when inflation is noticeable -- and history shows gold rises over the course of such cycles.
Christopher Aaron, Bullion Exchanges Market Analyst Christopher Aaron has been trading in the commodity and financial markets since the early 2000's. He began his career as an intelligence analyst for the Central Intelligence Agency, where he specialized in the creation and interpretation of pattern-of- life mapping in Afghanistan and Iraq. Technical analysis shares many similarities with mapping: both are based on the observations of repeating and imbedded patterns in human nature. His strategy of blending behavioral and technical analysis has helped him and his clients to identify both long-term market cycles and short-term opportunities for profit. This article is provided as a third party analysis and does not necessarily matches views of Bullion Exchanges and should not be considered as financial advice in any way.

item.title: Fed Hints at Rate Hike in December
item.dc:creator: jacobk
item.content:encoded:
While the Fed this week once again did not raise interest rates, the significant surge in precious metals seen on Wednesday was based on the change in the wording used in the accompanying policy statement. Whereas over the past few meetings the Fed has given little indication that it was considering a second interest rate hike, this time the central bank used the following distinct language: "The case for an increase in the federal funds rate has strengthened." As investors, we must remember that we are still living in an unprecedented age for low interest rates. At the 0.25% - 0.50% target rate, this is still the lowest that interest rates have been in the history of the Federal Reserve, including the following two critical time periods:
  • The Great Depression: rates hit a low of 1.5%
  • World War II: rates hit a low of 1.0%
Can we imagine that what is happening in the world economy currently must be deemed by the Federal Reserve to be more severe than both the Great Depression and the largest international conflict in the history of planet Earth? Not only are rates lower than in each of these periods, but they have been held lower for a greater number of years than at each of these previous troughs, now eight years and counting below the 1.0% mark. Of course, holding interest rates so low requires a continuous electronic "printing" of new money, which is used to buy the entire short-end of the interbank bond curve. The longer that rates are held below what the market would naturally set them at -- usually between 2.0% - 5.0% -- the more inflation the Fed is building underneath the system. The data to support this coming wave of inflation can be seen from the graph of the total reserve balances held at the Fed. Recall that what appears on this chart is money the Fed has created in order to buy sufficient bonds needed to force interest rates lower:     We can see that there is no precedent for the amount of money created since 2008. The Fed -- and other major world central banks -- have embarked on a money-printing spree that will go down in history as an experiment like none other. Note that there *is* a line on this graph dating back to 1950... it is just so low on the Y-axis that it barely registers when compared to the nearly $2.4 trillion created by the bank since 2008. The strange thing about inflation is that once central banks create it -- they cannot control precisely where it flows after it enters the broad economy. Similar to turning on a fire hose in an attempt to water the garden flowers, some may flow to the intended destination, but far more will eventually flow to unintended areas. Thus far, the recipients for most of the inflation are clear, and we have discussed them in past articles: world bond and stock markets, which are both at all-time highs simultaneously (in itself an unprecedented situation). But nothing happens in a vacuum. Newton's Third Law of Physics says: "For every action there is an opposite and equal reaction." And it appears that the unintended consequence of the Fed's actions are about to be felt elsewhere: in the US dollar.   US Dollar The chart below shows the US dollar as measured by the Dollar Index, a trade-weighted basket that measures the value of the US currency versus the sum of the following:
  • Euro (EUR), 57.6% weight
  • Japanese yen (JPY) 13.6% weight
  • Pound sterling (GBP), 11.9% weight
  • Canadian dollar (CAD), 9.1% weight
  • Swedish krona (SEK), 4.2% weight
  • Swiss franc (CHF) 3.6% weight
    We have been following this chart now for several months, as the dollar has been consolidating for nearly two years between the 92 level and the 100 level on the index. Over the long run, we expect gold and silver to be moving higher in all currencies, no matter what happens with one fiat currency versus another... but over the short run, gold tends to see its most significant advances when the US dollar is weak, as gold is priced primarily in US dollars for purposes of international trade. Thus, let us remember that the advance seen in gold from the December 2015 low of $1,045 per ounce to the recent high of $1,378 has taken place within a backdrop of a relatively stable US dollar, which has only fallen from 100 to 95 on the Index. It appears that gold is now waiting for further signals from the currency market in order to begin its next move, and as the dollar has continued to consolidate, so has gold. Yet these consolidations will not continue forever.   Recent Technical Analysis on the Dollar On the chart above, we can see converging sets of trendlines, shown in royal blue for primary downward trend and teal for short-term uptrend. These trends have been converging since December 2015 and May 2016, respectively. One of these trends is due to break within the next 4-8 weeks. While consolidations such as this are inherently neutral when viewed in isolation (they can break either upward or downward), when we view the action within the context of the preceding advance the nearly two-year consolidation in the dollar is increasingly taking the form of a broad long-term top. Indeed, it would be rare to see such a lengthy pattern result in a continuation move higher. From the short-term perspective, our "hints" that the break will be lower come from the two cracks in the support zone below 93 on the index. These cracks have been warning signs that buyers of the dollar are not as resolute in supporting the currency as many would believe. This is in contrast to the resistance zone at 100, which has shown very distinct and unhesitant selling pressure each time that level is reached. Should the lower converging (teal color) trendline break in the dollar in the coming weeks, the currency should be making new lows below the 92 region in short order. This move is expected to coincide with the converse breaking of the long-term downtrend that has held the price of gold lower from 2011 - present (see Gold Analysis, below).   Gold Analysis Gold made another attempt to overcome its long-term downtrend this week, reaching $1,343 on Thursday before falling back to $1,337 by the end of the week. This was the fifth attempt by gold to break higher from the current consolidation. Each attempt represents another opportunity as buyers chip away at the overhang of sellers. Although we cannot be certain exactly when the line is going to be crossed, a breakout of this magnitude will leave no doubts when it does occur.     Resistance is clearly defined by the downtrend as between $1,355 - $1,378. The rising blue trend channel since the December lows is now coming into focus for support near $1,310, and immediately below that the support zone that has held since June comes in between $1,285 - $1,305. Longer-term, we must remember that the bottom seen last December was nothing less than a retest of a multi-decade breakout from the 1980 - 2009 consolidation in gold. The move seen from 2009 - 2011 was the initial surge from the breakout. However, multi-decade breakouts do not tend to see their advances finish in two years only. A more significant advance is believed to be in the early stages of developing.    
Christopher Aaron, Bullion Exchanges Market Analyst Christopher Aaron has been trading in the commodity and financial markets since the early 2000's. He began his career as an intelligence analyst for the Central Intelligence Agency, where he specialized in the creation and interpretation of pattern-of- life mapping in Afghanistan and Iraq. Technical analysis shares many similarities with mapping: both are based on the observations of repeating and imbedded patterns in human nature. item.title: Perth Mint: New coin releases for November 2016
item.dc:creator: jacobk
item.content:encoded: Australia’s renowned Perth Mint will release in November five new exceptional coins, the 2016 ½ oz. Lynx Cubs Silver Proof Coin, the 2017 ½ oz. Baby Rooster Silver Proof Coin, the 2017 1 oz. Silver Gilded Year of the Rooster Coin, the 2017 1 oz. Year of the Rooster Silver Proof High Relief Coin and the 2017 $1 Australian Citizenship Coin, and a superb coin set, the 2016 Australian High Relief Silver Proof Three-Coin Collection.     November is a dazzling month for the Perth Mint with these astounding silver coin releases:   Australia’s iconic wildlife symbols - The 2016 High Relief Silver Proof 3-Coin set The Perth Mint offers a fantastic coin set that includes three of its most popular coins - the Australian Kangaroo, Koala, and Kookaburra. Each coin from this exclusive set showcases Perth Mint’s minting excellence, being produced from 1 oz. of .999 fine silver in high relief proof quality. The coins depict the famous Australian inhabitants: a kangaroo resting on its haunches, a koala walking along a eucalyptus branch and a kookaburra perched on a fence. The reverse sides also contain the name of the coin, the mintmark and the year of issue. Also, both the reverse and obverse sides of each coin are struck on concave surfaces to assure their exquisite high relief and proof finish. The Perth Mint provides this elegant set in a classic, black presentation case with a beautifully illustrated shipper and a numbered Certificate of Authenticity. The collection has an extremely limited issue of only 1,000 sets.   5th issue in the adorable Cubs series – Lynx Cubs 2016 ½ Silver Proof Coin Perth Mint will release the fifth and final coin in the charming Cub series – the adorable lynx cubs. This stunning coin is struck from ½ troy ounce of .999 fine silver in proof quality and has a mintage limit of just 5,000 coins. This exceptional Tuvalu legal tender coin displays on its reverse side two lovely, colored lynx cubs in the Canadian Rocky Mountains, encircled by the “P” mintmark and the inscription “CUBS.” The beautiful lynx is a solitary cat that inhabits the northern forests of North America, Asia, and Europe. This superb feline has tufts of black hair on its ears, a short, stubby tail and a thick fur that keeps it warm during freezing winters. The previous silver coins issued within the series featured the tiger, jaguar, snow leopard and white lion and all of them are offered in a special customized case. The Perth Mint also offers an elegant presentation box to display all of the five illustrated coin cases.   The 2017 $1 Australian Citizenship Coin Perth Mint will release its 2017 Australian Citizenship $1 Coin as an annual commitment to celebrating the proud and joyful milestone of acquiring the Australian Citizenship. This affordable, yet fantastic, legal tender coin is an exceptional gift and a treasured collectible that commemorates the “Pledge of Commitment” - the moving event for many new Australians. This outstanding aluminum bronze coin features on its reverse side the Australian Commonwealth Coat of Arms – a shield displaying the badges of the six States of the Commonwealth. The shield is enclosed by an ermine border signifying the Australian Federation in 1901 and its representation is encircled by the words “Australian Citizenship.” The coin is sold in a superb colored presentation card that incorporates a fold-out stand for upright display and the Certificate of Authenticity, making it a perfect keepsake for any Australian citizen.   The new 2017 lunar rooster coin editions Perth Mint offers three exceptional keepsakes for the lunar series enthusiasts and, also, perfect gifts for people born under the rooster sign: the 2017 1 oz. Year of the Rooster Silver Proof High Relief Coin, the 2017 1 oz. Silver Gilded Year of the Rooster Coin and the adorable 2017 ½ oz. Baby Rooster Silver Proof Coin. The high relief proof edition of the 1 oz. Silver Year of the Rooster coin is minted on a beautiful concave surface that enhances its exquisite high relief and proof finish. This sensational coin is made from 1 troy ounce of .9999 fine silver and has a limited mintage of just 7,500 pieces. The silver gilded version has a maximum mintage limit of 50,000 coins and is made from 1 oz. of 99.99% silver, depicting a 24-Karat gold gilded rooster. Both of these fantastic coins carry the same reverse design as the bullion and proof version – the rooster with its three chicks and a hen standing amongst a field of flowers and bamboo, followed by the ‘P’ mintmark, the Chinese character for ‘rooster’ and the engraving ‘Year of the Rooster.’ Perth Mint also delights its collectors with an excellent gift for any baby born in 2017 – the ½ oz. Baby Rooster Silver Proof Coin. This lovely 1 oz. .999 fine silver coin is issued with a mintage limit of just 7,500 coins and celebrates the Chinese ‘Year of the Rooster’ by displaying on its reverse side a colorful baby rooster against a backdrop of flowers. This cute image is surrounded by the Chinese character for ‘rooster,’ the inscription ‘Year of the Rooster’, and the year of issue, weight and purity of the coin. These thrilling coins are offered in a classic black presentation case, but the gilded version is also available for collectors encapsulated and in a special case for displaying the full 12 lunar coins set. ** The obverse sides of all the Perth Mint coins portray the famous effigy of Queen Elizabeth II, created by Ian Rank-Broadley, which is surrounded by the coin’s denomination, size and purity inscriptions, and the “Australia” engraving (except for the lynx cubs and baby rooster coins which contain the “Tuvalu” lettering).   About Perth Mint Perth Mint, the most prestigious Australian Mint, was established in 1899 by the Royal Mint. The British Mint opened its branch after Britons discovered vast gold deposits in Australia. Today, this premium refinery is accredited by COMEX, DMCC, TOCOM and LBMA, being famous for producing splendid bullion items such as: gold bars, coins, and silver coins, including the Lunar and Kangaroo series. The mint is also internationally renowned for creating the finest gold plate made of 13 troy ounces of .999999 pure gold in 1957, which was later used as a benchmark by the Royal Mint.

item.title: US Dollar and Gold Continue Positive Correlation
item.dc:creator: jacobk
item.content:encoded:
The positive correlation we were monitoring last week between the US dollar and the gold price has become even more pronounced since the last update. The US dollar, as measured by the Dollar Index, has continued to rise toward medium-term resistance on the charts near the 100 level. Meanwhile, gold is refusing to break down below its recent low of $1,243 set on October 7. These time periods in which both the US dollar and gold move in the same direction are rare, but not unheard of altogether. They tend to happen during one of two main scenarios: 1) Market panics -- when both assets are viewed as safe-havens, and rise simultaneously (or after the panic ends, when both fall simultaneously). 2) At major inflection points -- when one market is advancing, but the other market does not "believe" the legitimacy of the other market's move. We see no panic in the stock or currency markets recently, so it appears that as of today, it is gold which is not believing the US dollar's continued advance. The update below continues from our chart last week, and shows both gold and the US dollar since the recent gold low of $1,243 on October 7 (UUP is the proxy ETF for the US dollar index, GLD the proxy for gold):     In the absence of a market panic, this simultaneous movement by both gold and the US dollar in the same direction will not last forever. One of these markets will soon be proven "wrong". Should the dollar continue to advance toward the 100 level while gold remains firm, the precious metal will be signaling that the dollar is due to put in its final medium-term top of the nearly 2-year consolidation shown below, before the next reversal should take it below 92 into 2017:     However, should the dollar advance above 100 in a meaningful way, we would need to monitor the action in gold closely, as it could represent a major headwind for the precious metals market for at least the next year. As of present gold continues to show little respect for the dollar's advance. Note that on the chart above, the RSI indicator (top section) has once again approached the overbought level above 70, which has marked previous tops in the dollar to within a few weeks through 2015. Because the dollar is approaching important long-term resistance, we will continue to show the dollar/gold relationship on a regular basis over the coming months. Especially with the possibility of a Fed interest rate hike before the New Year, and with the US election only two weeks away -- the major currency markets are primed for trend-setting action through December.   Gold Update As of the New York COMEX close on Friday afternoon, gold had gained $12.20 for the week or nearly 1%, to close at $1,267.70. Looking ahead, initial resistance will be showing up in the former support zone which was broken during the early October decline, between $1,285 and $1,305. With a high probability, we expect buyers will need at least two distinct attempts to break through this resistance level. For support, we are looking for gold to continue stabilizing above or within the zone of $1,200 - $1,251, shown below in the green band. If gold can maintain the recent October 7 low of $1,243 as the bottom for this correction, it will be setting up a bullish posture to overcome the declining long-term downtrend (magenta color) as early as December, and at latest by March. We continue to believe the overcoming of this long-term downtrend will represent a major shifting point in the psychology of the precious metals market, and should precede a significant dollar-negative event by 6-12 months. We note that the RSI indicator (top of chart) had become the most oversold since just prior to the December 2015 bottom. In a bull market, RSI readings below 30 generally signify medium-term bottoms, although this does not preclude the possibility of further time needed within the support zone over the coming months.     ***** As the US election is just over two weeks away, during the next two weeks we will have increased commentary on how the election results may impact the markets, most notably the US stock market, and of course the precious metals.
Christopher Aaron, Bullion Exchanges Market Analyst Christopher Aaron has been trading in the commodity and financial markets since the early 2000's. He began his career as an intelligence analyst for the Central Intelligence Agency, where he specialized in the creation and interpretation of pattern-of- life mapping in Afghanistan and Iraq. Technical analysis shares many similarities with mapping: both are based on the observations of repeating and imbedded patterns in human nature. His strategy of blending behavioral and technical analysis has helped him and his clients to identify both long-term market cycles and short-term opportunities for profit. This article is provided as a third party analysis and does not necessarily matches views of Bullion Exchanges and should not be considered as financial advice in any way.

item.title: 2017 Chinese Silver Pandas now available at Bullion Exchanges
item.dc:creator: jacobk
item.content:encoded: The Chinese Silver Panda Coins, one of the most eagerly awaited numismatic issues, is now added to Bullion Exchanges comprehensive selection of coins. Its release date is October 28th (available in US in mid-December), announced by the People’s Bank of China, along with the official 2017 design of the coin – a lovely panda bear sitting down a bamboo background and eating a bamboo branch.     Get your stunning 2017 Chinese Silver Panda from Bullion Exchanges! Introduced in 1982 (first gold coin) and 1983 (first silver coin), the Chinese Panda program is one of the most highly anticipated series on the precious metals market. Coin enthusiasts and numismatists all over the world are anxiously waiting for each coin release due to their unique reverse designs that depict a new panda image each year (except for the 2001 and 2002 that share the same design). The People’s Bank of China has announced that the silver pandas will be available as of  the 28th of October, yet the coins will reach the US bullion market close to mid-December. The bank also announced this year’s design of the reverse side of the coin – a single panda eating a bamboo branch while sitting down on a bamboo background. This lovely image is surrounded by the face value of the coin, as well as its purity and weight. The 2017 reverse image is reminiscent of the 2015-coin edition, which contains the same elements but displayed from an opposite perspective. Some sources state that this year’s design is courtesy of a new mint designer, but this information is yet to be confirmed.     The renowned Hall of Prayer for Abundant Harvests, located in the Taoist Temple of Heaven from Beijing, is featured on the obverse side of the coin, followed by the inscriptions "中华人民共和国," the Chinese characters for “People’s Republic of China” and the mintage year “2017”. Starting with 2016, the Chinese Panda Coins are issued by the Chinese Mint with weights established according to the metric system. The 2017 releases continue the gram weight era, being produced from 30 grams of .999 fine silver, having a ¥10 Yuan face value and a limited issue of 10,000,000 coins. The proof silver and gold Chinese Pandas will be available in China beginning with December 15th and will display the same design of the coin. The 150-gram silver proof coin will carry a denomination of ¥50 Yuan, having a mintage limit of 60,000 coins, while the 1-kilo silver proof coin will bear a ¥100 Yuan face value and a limited issue of only 20,000 pieces. The 2017 Gold Pandas are struck in weights of 30 gr. (¥500 Yuan), 15 gr. (¥200 Yuan), 8 gr. (¥100 Yuan), 3 gr. (¥50 Yuan), and 1 gr. (¥10 Yuan), having an availability of 700,000 (30 gr.), 600,000 (8 and 15 gr.), 800,000 (3 gr.), and 1,000,000 (1 gr.). Four proof gold issues of 1 kilo (¥10,000 Yuan), 150 grams (¥2000 Yuan), 100 grams (¥1500 Yuan), and 50 grams (¥800 Yuan), with mintage limits of 500, 5,000, 10,000 and 20,000 pieces, will also be produced by the mint this year.   [embed]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-ZNWpkawuKg[/embed]   Bullion Exchanges offers you the 2017 30 gram Chinese Silver Panda Coin in its original mint packaging, as well as Mint State 69 (MS69), Mint State 70 (MS70) and Early Releases designations from the renowned NGC, displayed in gorgeous Red and Retro Holders.  The 2017 150 gram Chinese Silver Panda Proof Coin will also be available certified by NGC with Proof 69 (PF69) & Proof 70 (PF70).

item.title: 2017 brings the 1st Silver, Platinum, and new Gold Krugerrand Sizes
item.dc:creator: jacobk
item.content:encoded: In 2017, the South African Government celebrates the 50th anniversary of the first ever gold bullion coin in the world – the Gold Krugerrand. To commemorate 50 years of excellence in producing this stunning gold coin, the South African Mint will release several exceptional world premieres: the first 1 oz. Silver Krugerrand (released on December 5th, 2016), the first 1 oz. Proof Platinum Krugerrand and the first 50 oz., 5 oz., 1/20 oz., and 1/50 oz. Proof Gold Krugerrand. ** In 1967, the 1 oz. Gold Krugerrand was released to promote the South African gold and help it establish as an international investment vehicle. Today, the name Gold Krugerrand is the renowned worldwide symbol for investing in gold. However, the year 2017 will give you several new reasons to associate this prestigious name with the most exclusive and astounding coin releases on the bullion market:   The first 1 oz. Silver Krugerrand Enthusiast numismatists of the series have been waiting for a long time for the Krugerrand silver edition to debut. Over this period, many counterfeit silver Krugerrands have been confusing collectors that this coin exists. Finally, in 2017, The Silver Krugerrand became a reality, being also the first Krugerrand that carries an actual face value of 1 Rand. The coin showcases the same obverse and reverse designs of the original gold coin, created by Otto Schultz and Coert Steynberg, except for the content inscription and the small privy stamp with the encircled “50” engraving. The South African Mint will issue the first 1 oz. Silver Krugerrand from .999 pure silver, available in two versions: Premium Uncirculated, available from December 5th, 2016, (having a higher quality than the common Bullion Uncirculated), with a limited mintage of 500,000 coins, and Proof, with an issue limit of 15,000 coins. Also, a few of these coins will be included in some mint’s anniversary sets. The first 1 oz. Silver Krugerrand will be a fantastic addition, highly awaited by investors and collectors around the world for 50 years.   The first 1 oz. Proof Platinum Krugerrand The brand-new Silver Krugerrand is not the only anniversary achievement from the South African Mint. In 2017, the mint will also issue the very first 1 oz. Proof Platinum Krugerrand Coin. The 1,967 proof .9999 fine platinum coins with a 10 Rand face value will represent the mint’s unique commitment to celebrating the year when this famous coin was released for the first time - 1967. The coins will feature the same design as the original Krugerrands, except for the content engraving, and are expected to be highly collectible.   The first 50 oz., 5 oz., 1/20 oz., and 1/50 oz. Proof Gold Krugerrands The South African Ministry of Finance authorized the production of the 50 oz., 5 oz., 1/20 oz., and 1/50 oz. Gold Krugerrands – the biggest and smallest Krugerrands in history. These wonderful coins will be struck from .9167 pure gold, yet will contain their exact engraved amount of pure gold, just like all Gold Krugerrands. The coins will display the same design and will have a limited issue of 50,000 coins for 1/50 oz., 20,000 coins for 1/20 oz., 500 coins for 5 oz., and just 50 coins for the 50 oz. size. The last coin size is a huge sensation, having a 4” diameter and over 1.6 kg in weight, being the special 50th-anniversary edition of the Gold Krugerrand. The mint will also issue the standard 1 oz. coin with a special 50th anniversary privy mark.   The South African Mint The official mint of the Republic of South Africa has over 100 years of experience in producing high-quality circulation and commemorative coins. The South African Mint was founded in 1886 by Paul Kruger in Pretoria and was run by the British Royal Mint up until 1941. Starting from 1961, the mint produces the country’s official currency and the most renowned gold bullion coin highly praised by investors all over the world – the Gold Krugerrand.   The History of Gold Krugerrands The Gold Krugerrands were the first gold bullion coins designed to be a convenient way of owning some of the South African gold. The first Gold Krugerrand coin was struck by the South African Mint on the 3rd of July 1967 from 22K gold, yet contained exactly 1 oz. pure gold – a trademark of the mint’s excellence. Today, the term “Krugerrand” is known by millions of investors around the world. The coin’s name was inspired by the renowned South African President, Paul Kruger, and the country’s monetary currency – Rand. The obverse design of the coin was based on the ZAR (Zuid Afrikaansche Republiek) coin, also known as the Kruger Pond, which depicted the profile portrait of President Kruger. On the reverse side of the coin is engraved the stunning image of a prancing Springbok, the iconic African antelope. In 1980, the mint added three new fractional sizes: 1/10 oz., ¼ oz. and ½ oz. Each of these coins contains the exact amount of gold. Therefore, their weight is a little higher due to the additional content of copper. As the first gold bullion coin in the world, the Gold Krugerrand was an instant success on the bullion market and continues to be one of the most popular collectibles in the world.
